ml.alternet.security.auth

Interface CryptFormat

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ColonCryptFormat, CurlyBracesCryptFormat, ModularCryptFormat, PlainTextCryptFormat, UnixCryptFormat

    public interface CryptFormat
    Giving a crypt, allow to detect the right hasher suitable for checking a password validity.

    An instance doesn't work with every hash scheme and format available (some looks identical, and even may vary according to the applications), but only on those available by a specific application which have to define which ones are eligible.

    The CryptFormat is useful only for applications that have to take care of several crypt formats, typically in a legacy application where crypt passwords already exist. (see below how to register your own hasher with a simple LookupKey).

    For example, imagine that you have a family of crypt formats that are encoded in the form : "[SHA]QvQHx34cyGz2cjXj6cauQoAwtIg=" where the scheme appears in square brackets. Two things have to be done :

    1. create a CryptFormat instance that checks whether a crypt matches "[scheme]"
    2. create a Hasher that breakdown the crypt in different part and autoconfigure it if necessary.
     // "SquareBrackets" stands for the crypt format family name
 @ml.alternet.discover.LookupKey(forClass = Hasher.class, variant = "SquareBrackets/SHA")
public class SHAHasherWithSquareBrackets implements Hasher {
     // ...
 }

    Now, to check a crypt that may exist in several format, use :

    CredentialsChecker checker = new CredentialsChecker.$(
    ModularCryptFormat,
    CurlyBracesCryptFormat,
    PlainTextCryptFormat
);
if (checker.check(credentials, crypt)) {
    // authentication succeeds
} else {
    // authentication fails
}
    Author:
    Philippe Poulard

    • Field Detail

      • LOGGER

        static final Logger LOGGER
        A logger for this class.

    • Method Detail

      • resolve

        Optional<Hasher.Builder> resolve(String crypt)
        Get the hasher bound to a crypt.
        Parameters:
        crypt - The candidate crypt.
        Returns:
        A configurable hasher builder if the given crypt matches this crypt format.

      • family

        String family()
        The name of the family of crypt format.
        Returns:
        The family name, use as the first part of the variant of the hasher to lookup.

      • infoTemplate

        String infoTemplate()
        Return a 'template', that indicates how a crypt looks like. A template should at least have a 'scheme' and a 'scheme specific part'.
        Returns:
        The shape of the crypt format.
